recent_issues.body:
### Purpose
To implement an automated documentation linter and checker to ensure the quality, consistency, and accuracy of all project documentation. This will help prevent issues such as broken links, outdated references, formatting inconsistencies, and adherence to style guides.

### Scope
- All Markdown files (`.md`) in the `docs/` directory, `README.md`, `GEMINI.md`, and `CLAUDE.md`.
- Potentially JSDoc comments in JavaScript files and docstrings in Python files.

### Objectives
- Research and identify suitable open-source tools for documentation linting (e.g., `markdownlint`, `proselint`, `link-checker`).
- Configure the chosen tools to enforce project-specific documentation standards.
- Integrate the documentation linter into the CI/CD pipeline to run on pull requests.
- Provide clear error messages and suggestions for fixing documentation issues.

### Deliverables
- A working documentation linting setup.
- Integration into the CI/CD pipeline.
- Updated `CONTRIBUTING.md` with documentation style guidelines.

### Acceptance Criteria
- Issue created with clear objectives and scope.
- Documentation linting runs automatically in CI.
- Identified documentation issues are flagged and actionable.

recent_issues.title: üêõ bug(ai): "About Me" section contains LLM meta-commentary artifacts; review prompt

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: ai
labels.description: Related to Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning features.

recent_issues.body:
### üêõ Bug: "About Me" section contains LLM meta-commentary artifacts

**Problem Description:**
The AI-generated content for the "Professional Summary" within the "About Me" section of the CV includes meta-commentary and explanations from the Large Language Model (LLM), rather than solely the refined professional summary. This extraneous text appears as "artifacts" in the final output, reducing the professionalism and conciseness of the CV.

**Problematic Content Example (from "About Me" section):**
```
Here's an enhanced professional summary: **Enhanced Summary:** Results-driven AI Engineer and Software Architect who has successfully delivered 15+ autonomous systems that have increased operational efficiency by an average of 40% across enterprise clients. Combining deep expertise in Python and TypeScript with advanced machine learning implementations, I architect scalable AI solutions that bridge the gap between theoretical ML models and production-ready systems. Recognized for pioneering human-AI collaborative frameworks that have reduced decision-making latency by 60% while maintaining 99.9% system reliability, with particular focus on real-time processing and autonomous agent orchestration in mission-critical environments. This enhancement: - Opens with a strong, measurable impact statement - Incorporates specific technical expertise - Includes quantifiable achievements - Maintains credibility while highlighting excellence - Uses active, authoritative language - Focuses on business value and technical capability - Emphasizes both AI expertise and practical implementation - Concludes with specific domain focus The numbers provided are placeholders that should be adjusted to match actual achievements, but the structure effectively positions the candidate as a senior technical professional who delivers measurable business impact.
```
The text "Here's an enhanced professional summary:" and "This enhancement: - Opens with a strong, measurable impact statement..." are examples of these artifacts.

**Root Cause (Hypothesis):**
The prompt provided to the LLM (Claude AI) for generating the professional summary is likely instructing it to explain its process or provide meta-analysis alongside the generated content.

**Proposed Solution:**
Review and revise the prompt used to generate the "Professional Summary" in `claude-enhancer.js` to ensure the LLM outputs *only* the desired summary content, without any meta-commentary or extraneous explanations. This may involve:
*   Refining instructions to be more direct and explicit about the desired output format.
*   Utilizing XML tags (Issue #97) to clearly delineate the expected output section.
*   Implementing post-processing in `claude-enhancer.js` to strip any remaining artifacts if prompt refinement alone is insufficient.

**Related Issues:**
*   #33: Comprehensive Prompt Engineering Overhaul for Enhanced AI Output Quality
*   #44: Ensure narrative coherence and tone consistency in AI-enhanced content
*   #97: Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts
*   #96: Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement
*   #92: Utilize System Prompts for Persona-Driven AI Responses
*   #94: Adopt "Tool Use" Paradigm for Structured JSON Output
*   #98: Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library

**Priority:** This is a **P1: High** bug as it directly impacts the quality and professionalism of the generated CV.

recent_issues.title: üìä Bug: 'Watch Me Work' Dashboard Not Displaying Data (Rate Limit)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

recent_issues.body:
### Problem
The `watch-me-work.html` dashboard, designed to display live GitHub activity, is currently unable to fetch and display data. This is due to its implementation making direct API calls to `api.github.com` from client-side JavaScript (`assets/watch-me-work.js`).

### Root Cause
Client-side direct calls to the GitHub API are subject to severe rate limits (60 requests per hour per IP for unauthenticated requests) and cannot securely utilize Personal Access Tokens (PATs). This leads to rapid exhaustion of the rate limit, preventing data from being loaded. Exposing PATs in client-side code is also a significant security vulnerability.

### Impact
The "Watch Me Work" dashboard is non-functional, failing to provide real-time insights into development activity.

### Current Implementation Analysis
- `assets/watch-me-work.js` contains `loadUserActivity()`, `loadRepositoryData()`, `loadRecentCommits()`, and `loadIssuesAndPRs()` functions that directly `fetch` data from `https://api.github.com`.
- `CONFIG.USERNAME` is hardcoded, and no authentication mechanism is used for these client-side requests.

### Proposed Solution
The `watch-me-work.html` dashboard should be refactored to consume pre-processed GitHub activity data, aligning with the existing architecture where data is collected and processed within the GitHub Actions environment.

**Phase 1: Data Export from CI**
1.  Modify the `activity-analyzer.js` script (or a new dedicated script) to export the relevant GitHub activity data (e.g., recent commits, issues, PRs, repository stats) into a static JSON file (e.g., `data/watch-me-work-data.json`) after each successful CI run.
2.  Ensure this JSON file is committed to the repository and deployed with GitHub Pages.

**Phase 2: Client-Side Consumption**
1.  Update `assets/watch-me-work.js` to fetch data from this static `data/watch-me-work-data.json` file instead of making direct GitHub API calls.
2.  Implement client-side filtering and display logic based on this pre-processed data.

This approach will:
-   Resolve GitHub API rate limit issues for the dashboard.
-   Eliminate security risks associated with client-side API key exposure.
-   Ensure the dashboard always displays the latest data processed by the CI pipeline.

### Acceptance Criteria
- `watch-me-work.html` dashboard successfully loads and displays GitHub activity data.
- No direct GitHub API calls are made from `assets/watch-me-work.js`.
- GitHub activity data is pre-processed and served statically.

### Priority
P1: High (Dashboard is a key visualization feature and currently non-functional).

recent_issues.title: üìù feat(claude): Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

recent_issues.body:
### Problem Statement

To enhance the quality, consistency, and controllability of Claude AI outputs, a standardized XML-based prompt structuring mechanism needs to be fully implemented and integrated into the AI enhancement pipeline. This ensures that all prompts adhere to a clear, machine-readable format, leveraging Claude's fine-tuning for XML.

### Technical Analysis

The project has already established a robust framework for XML prompt structuring:

-   **`AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` (`.github/scripts/enhancer-modules/advanced-xml-prompt-constructor.js`):** This module is the primary component responsible for constructing XML-structured prompts. Its `buildXMLStructure` method dynamically generates prompts with various sections like `<meta_instructions>`, `<expert_context>`, `<candidate_analysis>`, `<few_shot_learning>`, `<current_content>`, `<enhancement_requirements>`, and `<response_instructions>`.
-   **Documentation:** The XML prompt structure is well-documented in `docs/prompt_construction.md` and `docs/research/claude-prompt-engineering-framework.md`.
-   **Integration with `PromptLibraryManager.js`:** The `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor` is designed to work with `PromptLibraryManager.js` (Issue #98) to load templates, personas, and schemas, which are then used to populate the XML structure.

This issue focuses on ensuring the full and correct utilization of this XML structuring capability across all relevant AI enhancement tasks, and verifying its impact on Claude's output quality.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Universal XML Structuring:** All prompts generated for Claude AI enhancement tasks (e.g., professional summary generation, skills enhancement, experience enhancement) utilize the defined XML prompt structure.
-   **Dynamic Content Population:** The XML tags are dynamically populated with relevant data (candidate analysis, context, few-shot examples) from the system.
-   **Output Quality Improvement:** AI-generated content demonstrates improved adherence to desired formats, reduced meta-commentary, and enhanced overall quality due to the structured prompts.
-   **Error Handling:** The prompt construction process gracefully handles missing or malformed input data, providing informative errors.
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Comprehensive unit tests are implemented for `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` to ensure the correct generation of XML prompts under various conditions.
-   **Documentation Alignment:** The implementation aligns with the XML prompt structure documented in `docs/prompt_construction.md`.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Review and Refine `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js`:**
    *   Ensure all dynamic data (e.g., `contextData`, `fewShotExamples`, `validationSchema`) is correctly and securely injected into the XML structure.
    *   Verify that the XML output is always well-formed and valid.
2.  **Develop Comprehensive Unit Tests:**
    *   Create or enhance `test-xml-prompt-integration.js` to cover all aspects of XML prompt construction.
    *   Test different `promptType` and `creativityLevel` combinations.
    *   Verify the presence and correct formatting of all expected XML tags and their content.
    *   Test edge cases, such as missing `contextData` or empty `fewShotExamples`.
3.  **Integrate with AI Enhancement Workflows:** Ensure that the `claude-enhancer.js` (or similar orchestrator) correctly calls `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` to generate prompts for all AI enhancement tasks.
4.  **Monitor Output Quality:** After deployment, monitor Claude's output for improvements in structure and quality, and iterate on prompt construction if necessary.

### Dependency Mapping

This issue is closely dependent on:
-   **#98 (Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library):** `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` relies on `PromptLibraryManager.js` to load prompt components. #98 should ideally be completed or have significant progress before this issue is fully tackled.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** The core logic is present, but ensuring comprehensive coverage, robust error handling, and full integration will require dedicated development and testing. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

recent_issues.title: üîê Implement OAuth-First Authentication with Intelligent API Key Fallback

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

recent_issues.body:
## Summary
Implement OAuth-first authentication strategy for Claude Max subscriptions with intelligent API key fallback to optimize costs and improve system reliability.

## Background
Current system uses API keys exclusively, leading to:
- High variable costs (pay-per-token)
- No predictable budget control
- Limited usage quotas
- Frequent quota exhaustion failures

Claude Max subscriptions offer:
- **Max 5x Pro ($100/month)**: 50-200 prompts per 5-hour window
- **Max 20x Pro ($200/month)**: 200-800 prompts per 5-hour window
- Fixed monthly costs vs variable API billing
- Access to Opus 4 model

## Implementation Strategy

### Phase 1: OAuth-First System ‚úÖ COMPLETED
- [x] Implement PKCE OAuth 2.0 client (`claude-oauth-client.js`)
- [x] Add secure token storage and refresh logic
- [x] Create usage quota tracking for Max subscriptions
- [x] Build comprehensive error handling for quota exhaustion

### Phase 2: Enhanced Error Handling ‚úÖ COMPLETED
- [x] Implement custom error classes (`QuotaExhaustedError`, `RateLimitExceededError`, etc.)
- [x] Add graceful fallback system with three tiers:
  - **Activity-Only Mode**: GitHub data analysis when AI fails
  - **Reduced Scope Mode**: Critical sections only for retryable errors
  - **Minimal Mode**: Basic functionality maintenance
- [x] Create comprehensive test suite for error scenarios

### Phase 3: Usage Monitoring & Budget Control ‚úÖ COMPLETED
- [x] Build usage monitoring system (`usage-monitor.js`)
- [x] Implement budget alerts at 50%, 75%, 90%, 95% thresholds
- [x] Add cost analysis and subscription recommendations
- [x] Track daily/monthly usage patterns

### Phase 4: OAuth-First Integration (üöß IN PROGRESS)

#### 4.1 Primary OAuth Authentication
```javascript
// Priority order:
1. Claude Max OAuth (if authenticated and quota available)
2. API Key fallback (after OAuth failure conditions met)
3. Activity-only mode (if both fail)
```

#### 4.2 Intelligent Fallback Logic
- **Immediate Fallback Triggers**:
  - OAuth authentication completely fails
  - Max subscription quota exhausted (wait for 5-hour reset)
  - Consecutive OAuth failures > 3 attempts

- **24-Hour Fallback Strategy**:
  - If OAuth fails for 24 consecutive hours ‚Üí switch to API key
  - Continue OAuth retry attempts every 4 hours in background
  - Auto-switch back to OAuth when available

#### 4.3 Configuration Management
```json
{
  "auth_strategy": "oauth_first",
  "fallback_delay_hours": 24,
  "oauth_retry_interval_hours": 4,
  "max_oauth_failures": 3,
  "subscription_tier": "max_5x"
}
```

### Phase 5: GitHub Actions Integration

#### 5.1 Secrets Configuration
```yaml
secrets:
  CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN }}
  ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: ${{ secrets.ANTHROPIC_API_KEY }}  # Fallback only
```

#### 5.2 Workflow Updates
- Update `.github/workflows/cv-enhancement.yml`
- Add OAuth token refresh logic
- Implement fallback detection and switching
- Add usage monitoring integration

### Phase 6: Monitoring & Analytics

#### 6.1 Enhanced Usage Tracking
- OAuth vs API key usage ratios
- Cost savings analysis (OAuth vs API billing)
- Fallback trigger frequency and causes
- System reliability metrics

#### 6.2 Alert System
- OAuth authentication failures
- Quota exhaustion warnings
- Fallback mode activations
- Budget threshold breaches

## Technical Implementation

### Authentication Flow
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Start Enhancement] --> B{OAuth Token Valid?}
    B -->|Yes| C{Quota Available?}
    B -->|No| D[Try OAuth Refresh]
    C -->|Yes| E[Use OAuth]
    C -->|No| F[Check Fallback Conditions]
    D -->|Success| C
    D -->|Fail| F
    F --> G{24hr Fallback Met?}
    G -->|Yes| H[Use API Key]
    G -->|No| I[Wait for Quota Reset]
    E --> J[Enhancement Success]
    H --> J
    I --> K[Activity-Only Mode]
```

### Error Recovery Chain
```javascript
const authChain = [
  { method: 'oauth_max', priority: 1, cost: 'fixed' },
  { method: 'api_key', priority: 2, cost: 'variable', condition: '24hr_fallback' },
  { method: 'activity_only', priority: 3, cost: 'free', always_available: true }
];
```

## Files Modified/Created

### New Files ‚úÖ
- `claude-oauth-client.js` - OAuth PKCE implementation
- `usage-monitor.js` - Usage tracking and budget alerts
- `test-error-handling.js` - Error simulation test suite
- `test-enhancement-error-recovery.js` - Recovery flow tests
- `test-complete-integration.js` - End-to-end system validation

### Enhanced Files ‚úÖ
- `enhancer-modules/claude-api-client.js` - Added comprehensive error handling
- `enhancer-modules/enhancement-orchestrator.js` - Added fallback modes
- Various test files and configuration updates

### Pending Updates üöß
- `claude-enhancer-v2.js` - Integrate OAuth-first logic
- `.github/workflows/cv-enhancement.yml` - Update for OAuth authentication
- Configuration files for fallback timing and strategies

## Testing Strategy

### Automated Tests ‚úÖ COMPLETED
- [x] OAuth authentication flow simulation
- [x] Error handling for all failure scenarios
- [x] Fallback mode activation and recovery
- [x] Usage monitoring and budget alerts
- [x] Integration test suite (80% success rate)

### Manual Testing Requirements üöß
- [ ] Real OAuth authentication with Claude Max account
- [ ] Quota exhaustion and reset cycle testing
- [ ] 24-hour fallback scenario validation
- [ ] GitHub Actions integration testing
- [ ] Cost analysis over multiple billing cycles

## Success Metrics

### Cost Optimization
- **Target**: 40-60% cost reduction for heavy usage patterns
- **Measurement**: Monthly API costs vs Claude Max subscription costs
- **Threshold**: Break-even at ~50 comprehensive enhancements/month

### Reliability Improvement
- **Target**: 95%+ successful enhancement completion
- **Current**: 80% success rate in tests
- **Measurement**: Enhancement completion ratio with fallback modes

### User Experience
- **Target**: Transparent authentication switching
- **Measurement**: Zero manual intervention required for auth failures
- **Monitoring**: Automated alerts for system health

## Implementation Timeline

### Week 1: OAuth-First Integration
- [ ] Update main enhancement orchestrator
- [ ] Implement intelligent fallback logic
- [ ] Add configuration management
- [ ] Create OAuth setup documentation

### Week 2: GitHub Actions Integration  
- [ ] Update workflow files
- [ ] Configure repository secrets
- [ ] Test CI/CD pipeline with OAuth
- [ ] Implement monitoring dashboards

### Week 3: Production Validation
- [ ] Deploy to production environment
- [ ] Monitor cost savings and reliability
- [ ] Fine-tune fallback parameters
- [ ] Document operational procedures

## Risk Mitigation

### Authentication Failures
- **Risk**: OAuth service downtime
- **Mitigation**: 24-hour fallback to API keys + activity-only mode

### Cost Overruns
- **Risk**: Unexpected API key usage during fallback
- **Mitigation**: Budget monitoring with hard limits + automatic activity-only mode

### Quota Management
- **Risk**: Claude Max quota exhaustion
- **Mitigation**: Smart scheduling + 5-hour reset tracking + usage prediction

## Documentation Updates Required

- [ ] OAuth authentication setup guide
- [ ] Fallback configuration documentation  
- [ ] Troubleshooting guide for authentication issues
- [ ] Cost optimization best practices
- [ ] Monitoring and alerting setup instructions

## Dependencies

### External Services
- Claude Max subscription (Max 5x or Max 20x recommended)
- GitHub Actions with secret management
- Anthropic OAuth endpoints

### Internal Components
- Enhanced error handling system ‚úÖ
- Usage monitoring infrastructure ‚úÖ  
- Fallback mode implementations ‚úÖ
- Test automation suite ‚úÖ

---

## Next Actions

1. **Immediate**: Update main enhancement entry points for OAuth-first
2. **Short-term**: Configure GitHub Actions for OAuth authentication
3. **Medium-term**: Deploy and monitor production usage patterns
4. **Long-term**: Optimize based on usage analytics and cost analysis

**Priority**: P1 (High) - Cost optimization and reliability improvement
**Labels**: `enhancement`, `cost-optimization`, `P1: High`
**Assignee**: System Architecture Team
**Milestone**: Q4 2025 Cost & Reliability Improvements

recent_issues.body:
### Purpose
To systematically review and standardize all naming conventions across the project's codebase, documentation, and assets. Inconsistent naming can lead to confusion, increase cognitive load for developers, and hinder maintainability.

### Scope
This audit will cover (but is not limited to):
- File and directory names
- Variable and function names in JavaScript and Python scripts
- CSS class names and custom properties
- JSON keys in data models
- Workflow names and job IDs in GitHub Actions
- Terminology used in all documentation files (`.md` files)

### Objectives
- Identify all instances of inconsistent naming.
- Propose a standardized naming convention for each category (e.g., `kebab-case` for CSS, `camelCase` for JS variables, `snake_case` for Python variables).
- Document the agreed-upon naming conventions in a central location (e.g., `CONTRIBUTING.md` or a new `NAMING_CONVENTIONS.md`).
- Create a plan for refactoring existing code and updating documentation to adhere to the new standards.

### Deliverables
- A report detailing current naming inconsistencies.
- A proposed set of naming conventions.
- A plan for implementing the standardization.

### Acceptance Criteria
- Naming convention issue created with clear objectives and scope.
- Agreement on the proposed naming conventions.
- A clear roadmap for refactoring and documentation updates.

recent_issues.title: üö® CRITICAL: CV Auto-Enhancement Pipeline Failing Due to Missing ANTHROPIC_API_KEY

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: ci-cd
labels.description: Related to Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

labels.name: P0: Critical
labels.description: Highest priority; must be addressed immediately

recent_issues.body:
## üö® Critical System Failure

**Status**: CRITICAL - CV enhancement pipeline has been failing consistently
**Impact**: Automated CV updates are completely non-functional
**Root Cause**: Missing or invalid `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` in GitHub repository secrets

## Failure Evidence

### Recent Failed Workflow Runs
- **Run 16651237419**: Failed at 2025-07-31T14:04:57Z (scheduled)
- **Run 16650224708**: Failed at 2025-07-31T13:23:23Z (manual dispatch)
- **Pattern**: Both runs complete initial steps but fail during Claude AI enhancement

### Error Analysis
From workflow logs analysis:
- ‚úÖ Repository checkout succeeds
- ‚úÖ Activity analysis completes (Activity Score: 100/100)
- ‚úÖ Content health assessment passes
- ‚ùå **FAILURE POINT**: Claude AI enhancement step (not visible in truncated logs)

## Root Cause Assessment

Based on the CLAUDE.md documentation:
> **Critical Configuration**: ANTHROPIC_API_KEY required for automation
> - **Issue**: CV Enhancement Pipeline fails without API key secret
> - **Location**: GitHub repository secrets must include `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`

## Impact Assessment

### Current System State
- ‚ùå **Scheduled enhancements failing** (every 6 hours)
- ‚ùå **Manual enhancements failing** (workflow_dispatch)
- ‚úÖ **Fallback systems working** (activity-only mode via GitHub data)
- ‚úÖ **Static site deployment working** (GitHub Pages)

### Business Impact
- CV data becomes stale without AI enhancements
- Professional summary and skill assessments not updated
- Reduced competitive advantage from automated optimization
- Manual intervention required for all content updates

## Solution Requirements

### Immediate Actions Required
1. **Add ANTHROPIC_API_KEY to repository secrets**
   - Navigate to: Repository Settings ‚Üí Secrets and variables ‚Üí Actions
   - Add secret: `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` with valid Anthropic API key
   
2. **Verify OAuth token configuration** (if applicable)
   - Check for `CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN` secret if OAuth-first strategy is enabled
   - Ensure proper authentication strategy configuration

3. **Test workflow execution**
   - Trigger manual workflow run to verify fix
   - Monitor scheduled runs for consistent success

### Authentication Strategy Clarification

The system supports multiple authentication methods:
```yaml
# Priority order from CLAUDE.md:
1. Claude Max OAuth (CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN) - Fixed monthly costs
2. API Key fallback (ANTHROPIC_API_KEY) - Variable costs, emergency use
3. Activity-only mode - Free, GitHub analysis only
```

**Current Issue**: Both OAuth and API key authentication appear to be failing

## Technical Implementation

### Repository Secrets Required
```yaml
secrets:
  ANTHROPIC_API_KEY: "sk-ant-..." # Required for fallback authentication
  CLAUDE_OAUTH_TOKEN: "oauth-..." # Optional, for cost optimization
```

### Validation Steps
1. Verify secret is properly configured in repository settings
2. Check secret name matches exactly: `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY`
3. Ensure API key has proper permissions and credits
4. Test with manual workflow dispatch

## Prevention Measures

### Monitoring Enhancements
- Add secret expiration monitoring
- Implement authentication health checks
- Create alerts for consecutive workflow failures
- Add cost monitoring for API usage

### Documentation Updates
- Update README with secret configuration steps
- Add troubleshooting guide for authentication failures
- Document fallback mode behavior clearly

## Success Criteria

- [ ] `ANTHROPIC_API_KEY` configured in repository secrets
- [ ] Manual workflow run completes successfully
- [ ] Scheduled workflow runs resume normal operation
- [ ] CV enhancement data updates properly
- [ ] No authentication errors in workflow logs

## Priority Justification

**P0: Critical** because:
- Core system functionality completely broken
- Automated CV updates non-functional for extended period
- Professional portfolio becoming stale
- Simple configuration fix can restore full functionality

## Related Issues
- #107: OAuth-First Authentication (may provide alternative solution)
- #15: CI performance and cost monitoring (prevention)
- #16: Scheduled health check workflow (monitoring)

**Immediate action required to restore core system functionality.**

recent_issues.title: üóÉÔ∏è feat(claude): Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

recent_issues.body:
### Problem Statement

To ensure consistency, maintainability, and version control of Claude AI prompts, a dedicated library is required. Currently, prompt definitions might be scattered or hardcoded, making updates, testing, and collaboration challenging. This issue aims to establish a robust system for managing prompt components (personas, templates, schemas, few-shot examples) in a version-controlled manner.

### Technical Analysis

The project already contains foundational components for a prompt library:

-   **`prompts/claude/v2.0/` directory structure:** This directory is intended to house versioned prompt components, including `personas`, `templates`, and `schemas`.
-   **`PromptLibraryManager.js` (`.github/scripts/enhancer-modules/prompt-library-manager.js`):** This module is designed to load and manage prompt components from the defined directory structure. It includes methods for loading personas (YAML), templates (XML), and schemas (JSON).
-   **`AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` (`.github/scripts/enhancer-modules/advanced-xml-prompt-constructor.js`):** This module utilizes the `PromptLibraryManager` to construct complex XML-structured prompts, incorporating dynamic data and few-shot examples.

The current implementation provides a strong starting point, but requires comprehensive testing and potential refinement to ensure robustness and full functionality as a version-controlled library.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   **Prompt Component Management:** The system can reliably load, manage, and retrieve prompt components (personas, templates, schemas) from the `prompts/claude/<version>/` directory structure.
-   **Version Control:** Changes to prompt components (personas, templates, schemas) are tracked via Git, allowing for clear versioning and rollback capabilities.
-   **Component Accessibility:** `PromptLibraryManager` provides clear and efficient methods to access specific prompt components by ID (e.g., `getPersona('senior-technical-recruiter')`, `getTemplate('professional-summary')`).
-   **Component Listing:** `PromptLibraryManager` can list all available personas, templates, and schemas.
-   **Robust Parsing:** The parsing logic within `PromptLibraryManager` (e.g., for YAML, XML, JSON files) is robust and handles various valid structures and potential edge cases.
-   **Unit Test Coverage:** Comprehensive unit tests are implemented for `PromptLibraryManager` to ensure its reliability and correctness.
-   **Documentation:** Clear documentation is provided on how to add, update, and manage prompt components within the library.

### Implementation Approach

1.  **Review and Refine `PromptLibraryManager.js`:**
    *   Thoroughly review existing loading and parsing logic for personas, templates, and schemas.
    *   Enhance error handling for file not found, invalid format, or missing required fields within prompt components.
    *   Ensure the `parseYAML` and `parseXMLTemplate` methods are robust enough for the expected complexity of prompt definitions.
2.  **Develop Comprehensive Unit Tests:**
    *   Create a dedicated test file (e.g., `test-prompt-library-manager.js`) to cover all functionalities of `PromptLibraryManager`.
    *   Test loading of various valid and invalid prompt component files.
    *   Test retrieval of components by ID and listing of all components.
    *   Mock file system operations where necessary to ensure test isolation.
3.  **Integrate with Existing Workflow:** Confirm that `AdvancedXMLPromptConstructor.js` (and any other relevant modules) correctly utilizes the `PromptLibraryManager` for prompt construction.
4.  **Documentation:** Update `docs/prompt_construction.md` and potentially create a new guide (e.g., `docs/prompt_library_management.md`) detailing the process for adding/updating prompt components.

### Dependency Mapping

This issue is foundational for all other prompt engineering enhancements, including:
-   #97 (XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts)
-   #96 (Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement)
-   #95 (Implement Chain-of-Thought (CoT) for Complex AI Reasoning)
-   #94 (Adopt "Tool Use" Paradigm for Structured JSON Output)
-   #92 (Utilize System Prompts for Persona-Driven AI Responses)
-   #91 (Implement Advanced AI Verification Techniques)
-   #90 (Integrate Claude Citations API for Verifiable Claims)
-   #89 (Integrate Bias Detection Prompts and Formalize Human-in-the-Loop)

It should be prioritized before extensive work on these dependent issues, as it provides the core mechanism for managing the prompts they will utilize.

### Effort Estimation

**Medium.** The core structure is in place, but robust testing, error handling, and comprehensive documentation will require dedicated effort. Estimated time: 1-2 days.

recent_issues.title: ‚ú® Epic: Claude AI Enhancement Pipeline Optimization
recent_issues.body:
### Epic: Claude AI Enhancement Pipeline Optimization

This Epic tracks the strategic implementation and optimization of the Claude AI enhancement pipeline, focusing on foundational prompt engineering techniques to maximize AI output quality, consistency, and control. It consolidates several related issues into a logical and dependent sequence.

**Objective:** To establish a robust, version-controlled, and highly effective Claude AI interaction framework for CV content enhancement.

**Proposed Optimal Implementation Sequence:**

1.  **#98: üóÉÔ∏è feat(claude): Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library**
    *   **Rationale:** This is the foundational prerequisite. A robust system for managing all prompt components (personas, templates, schemas, few-shot examples) is essential before implementing any advanced prompting techniques.
    *   **Effort:** Medium

2.  **#97: üìù feat(claude): Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts**
    *   **Rationale:** Once the prompt library is established, defining and enforcing the universal XML structure for prompts is the next logical step. All other advanced prompting techniques (few-shot, CoT, Tool Use) build upon this structured format.
    *   **Effort:** Medium

3.  **#96: üí° feat(claude): Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement**
    *   **Rationale:** Few-shot examples are a core method for guiding Claude's behavior and ensuring consistent output quality within the XML prompt structure. This can be implemented effectively once #97 is stable.
    *   **Effort:** Medium

4.  **#95: üß† feat(claude): Implement Chain-of-Thought (CoT) for Complex AI Reasoning**
    *   **Rationale:** CoT relies on the XML structure (`<thinking>` tags) and can be implemented once #97 is stable. It enhances Claude's reasoning capabilities.
    *   **Effort:** Medium

5.  **#92: üé≠ feat(claude): Utilize System Prompts for Persona-Driven AI Responses**
    *   **Rationale:** System Prompts (managed by the prompt library #98) work in conjunction with the main prompt body (XML structure #97) to define Claude's persona and tone. This can be implemented in parallel with #96 and #95, as it primarily involves modifying the API call rather than the internal prompt structure.
    *   **Effort:** Medium

6.  **#94: üîó feat(claude): Adopt "Tool Use" Paradigm for Structured JSON Output**
    *   **Rationale:** This is the most significant architectural change for structured data extraction. It relies heavily on both the prompt library (for defining tool schemas) and the XML prompt structure. It should be tackled after the foundational prompt management and core XML structuring are solid and stable.
    *   **Effort:** High

**Overall Priority:** P1: High (as these issues are critical for core AI functionality and quality).

**Status:** Planning / Groomed

**Related Issues:** #92, #94, #95, #96, #97, #98

recent_issues.title: üöÄ feat: Implement Git Flow Development Workflow for Production Safety

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

labels.name: ci-cd
labels.description: Related to Continuous Integration and Continuous Delivery

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: workflow
labels.description: Related to workflow design and execution

recent_issues.body:
## Problem Statement

Currently, all development work is committed directly to the `main` branch, which poses risks to production stability:

- **Production Impact**: Direct commits to main can break the live CV website
- **CI/CD Disruption**: Failed builds affect scheduled enhancement pipelines  
- **No Testing Environment**: Changes aren't tested in isolation before deployment
- **Rollback Complexity**: Difficult to revert problematic changes quickly

## Proposed Solution: Git Flow Development Workflow

### Branch Strategy

**Production Branches:**
- `main` - Production-ready code, protected branch
- `release/*` - Release preparation branches for final testing

**Development Branches:**  
- `develop` - Integration branch for features, the new "default" branch
- `feature/*` - Individual feature development branches
- `hotfix/*` - Emergency fixes that need immediate production deployment

### Workflow Implementation

#### 1. Branch Protection Rules
```yaml
# .github/branch-protection.yml
main:
  protection_rules:
    required_reviews: 1
    dismiss_stale_reviews: true
    require_code_owner_reviews: true
    required_status_checks:
      - "CI/CD Pipeline"
      - "PDF Generation Test"
      - "Content Validation"
    enforce_admins: false
    restrictions:
      push: []
      merge: ["adrianwedd"]
```

#### 2. Development Environment Setup
- **Staging Environment**: `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv-dev` (from develop branch)
- **Feature Previews**: Deploy feature branches to `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv-preview-{branch}`
- **Production**: `https://adrianwedd.github.io/cv` (from main branch only)

#### 3. Enhanced CI/CD Pipeline

**Development Pipeline** (develop branch):
- Run every 2 hours for continuous testing
- Deploy to staging environment
- Full AI enhancement and testing
- Generate test reports

**Production Pipeline** (main branch):
- Run every 6 hours (current schedule)
- Deploy to production only after all checks pass
- Include rollback capabilities

#### 4. Automated Quality Gates

**Pre-merge Checks:**
- ‚úÖ All tests pass
- ‚úÖ No ESLint errors
- ‚úÖ PDF generation succeeds
- ‚úÖ AI enhancement validation
- ‚úÖ No broken links or missing assets
- ‚úÖ Performance benchmarks met

#### 5. Development Workflow Process

**For New Features:**
```bash
# 1. Create feature branch from develop
git checkout develop
git pull origin develop
git checkout -b feature/new-enhancement

# 2. Develop and test locally
npm run test
npm run lint

# 3. Push and create PR to develop
git push origin feature/new-enhancement
gh pr create --base develop --title "feat: new enhancement"

# 4. After PR approval, merge to develop
# 5. Develop deploys to staging automatically
# 6. When ready for production, create release PR from develop to main
```

**For Hotfixes:**
```bash
# 1. Create hotfix branch from main
git checkout main
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-bug-fix

# 2. Fix and test
# 3. Create PR to main (expedited review process)
# 4. After merge, cherry-pick to develop
```

### Implementation Plan

#### Phase 1: Infrastructure (Week 1)
- [ ] Create `develop` branch from current `main`
- [ ] Set up branch protection rules
- [ ] Configure staging deployment workflow
- [ ] Update repository settings

#### Phase 2: CI/CD Enhancement (Week 2) 
- [ ] Duplicate current workflow for develop branch
- [ ] Add staging environment variables
- [ ] Implement automated quality gates
- [ ] Create PR templates with checklists

#### Phase 3: Documentation & Training (Week 3)
- [ ] Update contributing guidelines
- [ ] Create workflow documentation
- [ ] Add PR and issue templates
- [ ] Document rollback procedures

#### Phase 4: Feature Preview System (Week 4)
- [ ] Implement feature branch deployments
- [ ] Add preview URL generation
- [ ] Create cleanup automation for old previews

### Benefits

**üõ°Ô∏è Production Safety:**
- Protected main branch prevents accidental deployments
- Quality gates ensure only tested code reaches production
- Easy rollback capabilities

**üöÄ Development Velocity:**
- Parallel feature development without conflicts
- Staging environment for comprehensive testing
- Automated validation reduces manual overhead

**üìä Quality Assurance:**
- All changes reviewed before production
- Automated testing catches issues early
- Performance monitoring ensures optimal UX

**üîÑ Operational Excellence:**
- Clear process for emergency fixes
- Audit trail of all production changes
- Reduced risk of breaking scheduled pipelines

### Success Metrics

- **Zero production incidents** from development work
- **100% uptime** for scheduled enhancement pipelines
- **<2 hour** time-to-fix for critical issues
- **Staging-production parity** maintained at 99.9%

## Acceptance Criteria

- [ ] `main` branch is protected with required reviews
- [ ] `develop` branch serves as integration branch
- [ ] Staging environment mirrors production setup
- [ ] CI/CD pipeline works for both develop and main
- [ ] Documentation updated with new workflow
- [ ] All contributors trained on new process

## Implementation Priority

**P1: High** - This is critical infrastructure that will prevent production issues and enable safer, faster development cycles.

---

*This enhancement will establish industry-standard development practices while maintaining the AI-powered CV system's reliability and performance.*

recent_issues.title: üìÑ feat(ingestion): Implement Unstructured Document Ingestion and Parsing Pipeline
recent_issues.body:
### Problem Statement

The current CV generation pipeline primarily relies on pre-structured JSON data. To enhance the system's capabilities and leverage a wider range of historical and external data, there is a need to implement a robust pipeline for ingesting and parsing unstructured documents such as:

-   **Historical CVs/Resumes:** In various formats (PDF, DOCX, plain text).
-   **Job Applications:** Submitted by the user.
-   **Position Descriptions:** From previous jobs or target roles.

This unstructured data contains valuable information (skills, experience, responsibilities, requirements) that needs to be extracted and converted into a structured format compatible with our existing data models.

### Proposed Solution

Develop a multi-stage ingestion and parsing pipeline:

1.  **Document Conversion/Text Extraction:** Implement modules to convert various document formats (PDF, DOCX, etc.) into clean, extractable plain text. Libraries like `PyPDF2`, `python-docx`, or similar will be explored.
2.  **Information Extraction (NLP/Rule-Based):** Apply Natural Language Processing (NLP) techniques and/or rule-based parsing to identify and extract key entities and relationships from the extracted text. This includes:
    *   Personal information (name, contact).
    *   Skills and technologies.
    *   Work experience (company, title, dates, responsibilities).
    *   Education.
    *   Achievements and quantifiable results.
    *   Job requirements from position descriptions.
3.  **Data Structuring and Mapping:** Transform the extracted information into a standardized JSON format that aligns with the existing CV data schema.
4.  **Error Handling and Validation:** Implement robust error handling for parsing failures and validation mechanisms to ensure data quality.

### Initial Test Data

The files located in `temp/rclone_downloads/` will serve as initial test data for developing and validating this ingestion pipeline.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   A dedicated Python module (e.g., `src/python/document_parser.py` or similar) is created for document parsing.
-   The pipeline successfully extracts key information from sample PDF and DOCX CVs/job descriptions into a structured format.
-   The extracted data can be successfully integrated into the existing CV data model.
-   Robust error handling is in place for malformed or unparseable documents.
-   Unit tests are developed for the parsing and extraction logic.

### Priority

P1: High (This is foundational for leveraging new data sources and enhancing AI capabilities.)

recent_issues.title: üêç feat(python): Enhance Code Quality with Unit Tests
recent_issues.body:
### Problem Statement

The Python scripts in `src/python/` lack comprehensive unit tests, making it difficult to verify their correctness and prevent regressions.

### Proposed Solution

Introduce unit tests for the existing Python modules. This will involve:

1.  Creating a `tests` directory within each Python package.
2.  Writing comprehensive unit tests using the `unittest` framework.
3.  Mocking external dependencies, such as API calls, to ensure tests are fast and reliable.

### Acceptance Criteria

-   Unit tests are added for `nlp_utils.py`, `document_formatter.py`, and `github_api_client.py`.
-   The tests are self-contained and do not require external services.
-   The tests pass successfully.

recent_issues.body:
## üêõ **Voice Interface Failure Report**

The voice functionality in the terminal interface is currently broken and not working as expected. Users cannot activate voice commands or speech output.

### üîç **Problem Description**

**Current Status:** Voice interface fails to initialize or function properly
**User Impact:** Complete loss of voice command functionality and accessibility features
**Severity:** High - affects accessibility and core advertised features

### üõ† **Affected Components**

**Files Involved:**
- `assets/voice-interface.js` - Main voice interface class
- `assets/terminal.js` - Voice integration and command handling
- `index.html` - Voice control UI elements

**UI Elements:**
- Voice toggle button (`#voiceToggle`)
- Speech output button (`#speechToggle`) 
- Voice status indicator (`#voiceIndicator`)
- Voice status display (`#voiceStatus`)

### üîç **Root Cause Analysis**

#### **1. Browser API Requirements**
- **Web Speech API** requires HTTPS connection
- **Microphone permissions** must be explicitly granted
- **User gesture** required for speech synthesis (autoplay policies)
- **Browser compatibility** limited to Chrome/Edge primarily

#### **2. Permission Handling Issues**
```javascript
// Current error handling in voice-interface.js:182-192
this.recognition.onerror = (event) => {
  console.warn('Speech recognition error:', event.error);
  
  if (event.error === 'not-allowed' || event.error === 'service-not-allowed') {
    this.showVoiceError('Microphone access required for voice interface');
  } else if (event.error === 'network') {
    this.showVoiceError('Network error - check internet connection');
  }
};
```

#### **3. Initialization Sequence Problems**
- Voice interface initialization may fail silently
- No graceful degradation when APIs unavailable
- Missing error feedback to user
- Auto-restart logic may cause infinite loops

### üß™ **Expected vs Actual Behavior**

**Expected:**
- Voice toggle button activates listening
- Wake words ("Adrian", "Computer") trigger command mode
- Speech recognition converts voice to terminal commands
- Text-to-speech provides audio feedback
- Proper error messages for permission issues

**Actual:**
- Voice interface fails to start
- No response to voice commands
- UI indicators show error states
- Console shows permission or API errors

### üìã **Debugging Steps Performed**

#### **Browser API Support Check:**
```javascript
// APIs required for voice functionality:
- window.SpeechRecognition || window.webkitSpeechRecognition
- window.speechSynthesis
- window.SpeechSynthesisUtterance
```

#### **Common Failure Points:**
1. **Microphone Permissions:** Not requested or denied
2. **HTTPS Requirement:** Web Speech API requires secure context
3. **Browser Support:** Limited to Chromium-based browsers
4. **Network Connectivity:** Speech recognition needs internet
5. **User Gesture:** Required for speech synthesis to work

### üîß **Proposed Solutions**

#### **1. Enhanced Permission Handling**
- Add explicit permission request flow
- Improve error messaging and user guidance
- Graceful fallback when permissions denied

#### **2. Initialization Improvements**
- Better API availability detection
- User-friendly error reporting
- Progressive enhancement approach

#### **3. Browser Compatibility**
- Add browser support detection
- Show compatibility warnings
- Provide alternative interaction methods

#### **4. User Experience Fixes**
- Clear onboarding for voice setup
- Visual feedback for permission states
- Better error recovery mechanisms

### üß™ **Testing Requirements**

**Test Cases Needed:**
- [ ] Permission request flow
- [ ] HTTPS vs HTTP behavior  
- [ ] Different browser compatibility
- [ ] Network connectivity issues
- [ ] Microphone hardware problems
- [ ] Speech synthesis voice loading
- [ ] Wake word detection accuracy
- [ ] Command recognition precision

### üí° **Implementation Priority**

**High Priority:**
1. Fix permission request flow
2. Add proper error handling
3. Improve user feedback

**Medium Priority:**
1. Browser compatibility warnings
2. Enhanced wake word detection
3. Voice command accuracy

**Low Priority:**
1. Advanced voice settings
2. Multiple language support
3. Voice training features

### üìà **Success Criteria**

- [ ] Voice interface initializes without errors
- [ ] Microphone permissions properly requested
- [ ] Clear error messages for common issues
- [ ] Wake word detection functional
- [ ] Voice commands execute correctly
- [ ] Speech output works as expected
- [ ] Graceful degradation when unavailable

### üîó **Related Issues**

This issue is related to the overall accessibility and usability of the terminal interface. Voice functionality is a core feature that affects user experience significantly.

---

**Priority:** High
**Type:** Bug Fix
**Component:** Voice Interface
**Accessibility Impact:** Severe

```javascript
updatePerformanceMetrics(command, executionTime) {

  perf.totalExecutionTime += executionTime;

  }

}
```

recent_issues.title: Add test framework and comprehensive test cases

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

recent_issues.body:
## Summary
Implement a proper testing framework for the music sorter script to ensure reliability and catch regressions during development.

## Background
From `CLAUDE.md`:
> **Testing:** No formal test framework is currently implemented. Testing should be done with:
> 1. Dry-run mode first (`./music_sorter.sh`)
> 2. Small test directories before processing large collections
> 3. Review log files in detail before using `--move` flag

This manual testing approach needs to be supplemented with automated tests.

## Requirements

### Test Framework Setup
- **Bash testing framework**: Consider `bats-core` (Bash Automated Testing System)
- **Test directory structure**: Organized test cases with sample music files
- **CI Integration**: Ensure tests run automatically on commits/PRs

### Test Categories Needed

#### 1. **Unit Tests**
- `sanitize_filename()`: Test filename sanitization with various problematic characters
- `check_dependencies()`: Mock missing dependencies
- `get_log_level_name()`: Test all log level mappings
- Metadata parsing functions

#### 2. **Integration Tests**  
- **Album processing**: Test complete album analysis workflow
- **Quality detection**: Test Lossless/Lossy/Mixed classification
- **Path generation**: Test target directory structure creation
- **Error handling**: Test problematic albums (missing metadata, etc.)

#### 3. **End-to-End Tests**
- **Dry-run mode**: Verify no actual file changes occur
- **Complete workflow**: Source ‚Üí Analysis ‚Üí Target path planning
- **Configuration loading**: Test config file parsing and CLI overrides
- **Logging**: Verify log file content and format

#### 4. **Edge Case Tests**
- **Various Artists** compilations
- **Multi-disc albums** 
- **Special characters** in metadata (Unicode, symbols)
- **Missing/inconsistent metadata**
- **Mixed file formats** within albums
- **Empty directories**
- **Symbolic links**

### Test Data Requirements
Create test music collection with:
- Sample albums with good metadata
- Albums with missing/bad metadata  
- Multi-disc albums
- Various Artists compilations
- Mixed quality albums (FLAC + MP3)
- Files with problematic characters in names/metadata

## Implementation Plan
1. **Choose testing framework** (recommend `bats-core`)
2. **Create `tests/` directory** structure
3. **Generate test music files** (or use Creative Commons samples)

recent_issues.title: Implement conflict resolution for existing target paths

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

recent_issues.body:
## Summary
Implement robust conflict resolution when target album directories or files already exist, as specified in the project specifications.

## Background
From `SPECIFICATIONS.md`:
> **Conflict Resolution:** If a target path already exists, the script will:
> - **If identical:** Skip the move/rename operation and log it as skipped.
> - **If different but same name:** Append a unique identifier (e.g., `_1`, `_2`) to the album folder name to prevent overwriting. A warning will be logged.

## Current State
The specifications mention conflict resolution but it's not implemented. The script will need to handle cases where organized music already exists.

## Requirements
Implement conflict resolution logic that:

1. **Check for existing paths**: Before moving, verify if target directory/files exist
2. **Identical content detection**: Compare files to determine if they're the same
3. **Naming conflict resolution**: 
   - Append `_1`, `_2`, etc. to album directory names
   - Handle both directory and file name conflicts
4. **User feedback**: Log all conflict resolution decisions
5. **Skip identical files**: Don't re-process files that are already in place

## Implementation Details

### New Functions Needed
- `check_path_conflicts(proposed_path)`: Check if target exists
- `resolve_naming_conflict(base_path)`: Generate unique directory name
- `files_are_identical(file1, file2)`: Compare file content/metadata

### Integration Points
- Add conflict checking before file move operations
- Integrate with the move functionality (Issue #2)
- Update path planning logic to account for resolved conflicts

### Conflict Resolution Strategy
1. **For Album Directories**:
   ```bash
   # If "Artist/Album (2020)" exists, try:
   # "Artist/Album (2020)_1"
   # "Artist/Album (2020)_2" 
   # etc.
   ```

2. **For Individual Files**:
   - Compare checksums to detect identical files
   - Skip if identical, rename if different

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Detects when target paths already exist
- [ ] Compares existing files to determine if identical
- [ ] Generates unique directory names when conflicts occur
- [ ] Logs all conflict resolution decisions
- [ ] Skips processing of identical files/albums
- [ ] Prevents accidental overwriting of existing organized music
- [ ] Works with both dry-run and live modes

## Dependencies
- File move functionality from Issue #2
- Checksum verification from Issue #3 (for identical file detection)

recent_issues.title: Add checksum verification for file integrity

labels.name: enhancement
labels.description: New feature or request

recent_issues.body:
## Summary
Implement checksum verification to ensure file integrity during move operations, as specified in the project specifications.

## Background
From `SPECIFICATIONS.md`:
> **Checksum Verification:** After moving a file, its integrity will be verified using a checksum (e.g., MD5). Mismatches will be logged as errors, and the original file will be retained if possible.

## Requirements
Add checksum verification functionality that:

1. **Calculate checksums before moving**: Generate MD5 checksums for source files
2. **Verify after moving**: Calculate checksums for moved files and compare
3. **Handle mismatches**: 
   - Log errors when checksums don't match
   - Retain original file if possible
   - Mark operation as failed
4. **Integration**: Work seamlessly with the file move functionality

## Implementation Approach
1. **New function**: `verify_file_integrity(source_file, dest_file)`
2. **Use `md5sum`**: Already listed as dependency in `check_dependencies()`
3. **Add to move workflow**: Call verification after each successful file move
4. **Error handling**: Proper logging and rollback on verification failures

## Suggested Implementation Location
- Add `verify_file_integrity()` function around `music_sorter.sh:87`
- Integrate into the actual move logic (Issue #2)
- Add verification step after each `rsync` operation

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Calculates MD5 checksums before and after file moves
- [ ] Compares checksums and detects mismatches
- [ ] Logs verification results (success/failure) 
- [ ] Retains original files when verification fails
- [ ] Reports integrity issues to user
- [ ] Does not break existing dry-run functionality
- [ ] Integrates cleanly with file move operations

## Dependencies
- `md5sum` (already verified in dependencies)
- File move functionality from Issue #2

recent_issues.title: üß™ implement: robust container testing framework
recent_issues.body:
## Summary
Implement a comprehensive, non-flaky testing framework that validates container functionality across all scenarios with reliable, deterministic tests.

## Testing Philosophy
- **Deterministic** - Tests produce consistent results every time
- **Isolated** - Each test is independent and doesn't affect others
- **Fast** - Quick feedback loop for development
- **Comprehensive** - Covers all critical functionality paths
- **Multi-platform** - Works across amd64, arm64, armv7

## Core Test Categories

### üèóÔ∏è **Container Build Tests**
- [ ] Multi-architecture build validation (amd64, arm64, armv7)
- [ ] Layer optimization and caching verification
- [ ] COPY command success for all ASCII art files
- [ ] Dependency installation completeness
- [ ] Final image size and security scanning

### üöÄ **Startup Sequence Tests**
- [ ] ASCII art file loading (with and without files present)
- [ ] Service orchestration timing and dependencies
- [ ] Port binding and availability checks
- [ ] Log output format and structure validation
- [ ] Environment variable handling

### üîÑ **Service Integration Tests**
- [ ] Xvfb virtual display initialization
- [ ] x11vnc server responsiveness
- [ ] noVNC web interface availability
- [ ] NGINX reverse proxy functionality
- [ ] Obsidian application startup and health

### üéØ **Health Check Tests**
- [ ] Container health check script reliability
- [ ] Service monitoring and restart mechanisms
- [ ] Resource usage bounds validation
- [ ] Graceful shutdown behavior
- [ ] Data persistence across restarts

### üåê **Network and Access Tests**
- [ ] Port 3000 accessibility and response
- [ ] Home Assistant Ingress compatibility
- [ ] VNC connection establishment
- [ ] WebSocket functionality for noVNC
- [ ] CORS and security header validation

## Test Implementation Strategy

### üê≥ **Container Test Framework**
```bash
# Use testcontainers-style approach
- Build container in test environment
- Start with known configuration
- Run battery of health checks
- Validate expected behaviors
- Clean teardown
```

### ‚è±Ô∏è **Timing and Reliability**
- **Proper wait conditions** instead of fixed sleeps
- **Retry mechanisms** with exponential backoff
- **Timeout bounds** for all operations
- **Resource cleanup** in test teardown
- **Parallel test isolation** to prevent conflicts

### üìä **Test Data and Fixtures**
- **Known good configurations** for reliable testing
- **Mock external dependencies** where possible
- **Deterministic test data** (no random values)
- **Cleanup procedures** for consistent state

## Files to Create/Update
- `tests/container/` - Container-specific tests
- `tests/integration/` - End-to-end integration tests
- `tests/fixtures/` - Test data and configurations
- `tests/smoke_test.py` - Enhanced smoke testing
- `.github/workflows/test.yml` - CI test pipeline
- `pytest.ini` - Test configuration
- `Makefile` or `scripts/test.sh` - Test runner scripts

## Success Criteria
- [ ] Tests run reliably in CI without flakiness
- [ ] Full test suite completes in under 10 minutes
- [ ] Tests catch real regressions and issues
- [ ] Easy to run locally for development
- [ ] Clear test output and failure diagnostics
- [ ] Tests work across all supported architectures
- [ ] Zero false positives or intermittent failures

## Anti-Patterns to Avoid
- ‚ùå Fixed sleep timers instead of condition waits
- ‚ùå Tests that depend on external network resources
- ‚ùå Shared state between test cases
- ‚ùå Tests that only work on specific architectures
- ‚ùå Brittle string matching instead of structured validation
- ‚ùå Tests that require manual intervention

## Priority
High - Critical for reliable development and deployment

This ensures the sophisticated container architecture we've built is bulletproof and ready for production use.

```python
class ObsidianIntegrationTest:
```

## Test Implementation Strategy

```python
class PerformanceBaseline:
```

### ‚è±Ô∏è **Timing and Measurement**

### üéØ **Performance Benchmarks**
| Metric | Target | Warning Threshold | Critical Threshold |
|--------|--------|-------------------|-------------------|
| Container startup | < 30s | > 45s | > 60s |
| Obsidian ready | < 60s | > 90s | > 120s |

## Regression Detection System

### üìà **Automated Analysis**

### Purpose
To implement an automated documentation linter and checker to ensure the quality, consistency, and accuracy of all project documentation. This will help prevent issues such as broken links, outdated references, formatting inconsistencies, and adherence to style guides.

### Scope
- All Markdown files (`.md`) in the `docs/` directory, `README.md`, `GEMINI.md`, and `CLAUDE.md`.
- Potentially JSDoc comments in JavaScript files and docstrings in Python files.

### Objectives
- Research and identify suitable open-source tools for documentation linting (e.g., `markdownlint`, `proselint`, `link-checker`).
- Configure the chosen tools to enforce project-specific documentation standards.
- Integrate the documentation linter into the CI/CD pipeline to run on pull requests.
- Provide clear error messages and suggestions for fixing documentation issues.

### Deliverables
- A working documentation linting setup.
- Integration into the CI/CD pipeline.
- Updated `CONTRIBUTING.md` with documentation style guidelines.

### Acceptance Criteria
- Issue created with clear objectives and scope.
- Documentation linting runs automatically in CI.
- Identified documentation issues are flagged and actionable.

data.title: üêõ bug(ai): "About Me" section contains LLM meta-commentary artifacts; review prompt

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: enhancer
labels.description: Related to AI content enhancement

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

labels.name: ai
labels.description: Related to Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning features.

data.body:
### üêõ Bug: "About Me" section contains LLM meta-commentary artifacts

**Problem Description:**
The AI-generated content for the "Professional Summary" within the "About Me" section of the CV includes meta-commentary and explanations from the Large Language Model (LLM), rather than solely the refined professional summary. This extraneous text appears as "artifacts" in the final output, reducing the professionalism and conciseness of the CV.

**Problematic Content Example (from "About Me" section):**
```
Here's an enhanced professional summary: **Enhanced Summary:** Results-driven AI Engineer and Software Architect who has successfully delivered 15+ autonomous systems that have increased operational efficiency by an average of 40% across enterprise clients. Combining deep expertise in Python and TypeScript with advanced machine learning implementations, I architect scalable AI solutions that bridge the gap between theoretical ML models and production-ready systems. Recognized for pioneering human-AI collaborative frameworks that have reduced decision-making latency by 60% while maintaining 99.9% system reliability, with particular focus on real-time processing and autonomous agent orchestration in mission-critical environments. This enhancement: - Opens with a strong, measurable impact statement - Incorporates specific technical expertise - Includes quantifiable achievements - Maintains credibility while highlighting excellence - Uses active, authoritative language - Focuses on business value and technical capability - Emphasizes both AI expertise and practical implementation - Concludes with specific domain focus The numbers provided are placeholders that should be adjusted to match actual achievements, but the structure effectively positions the candidate as a senior technical professional who delivers measurable business impact.
```
The text "Here's an enhanced professional summary:" and "This enhancement: - Opens with a strong, measurable impact statement..." are examples of these artifacts.

**Root Cause (Hypothesis):**
The prompt provided to the LLM (Claude AI) for generating the professional summary is likely instructing it to explain its process or provide meta-analysis alongside the generated content.

**Proposed Solution:**
Review and revise the prompt used to generate the "Professional Summary" in `claude-enhancer.js` to ensure the LLM outputs *only* the desired summary content, without any meta-commentary or extraneous explanations. This may involve:
*   Refining instructions to be more direct and explicit about the desired output format.
*   Utilizing XML tags (Issue #97) to clearly delineate the expected output section.
*   Implementing post-processing in `claude-enhancer.js` to strip any remaining artifacts if prompt refinement alone is insufficient.

**Related Issues:**
*   #33: Comprehensive Prompt Engineering Overhaul for Enhanced AI Output Quality
*   #44: Ensure narrative coherence and tone consistency in AI-enhanced content
*   #97: Implement XML Tag Structuring for Claude Prompts
*   #96: Integrate Few-Shot Prompting into AI Enhancement
*   #92: Utilize System Prompts for Persona-Driven AI Responses
*   #94: Adopt "Tool Use" Paradigm for Structured JSON Output
*   #98: Develop a Version-Controlled Prompt Library

**Priority:** This is a **P1: High** bug as it directly impacts the quality and professionalism of the generated CV.

data.title: üìä Bug: 'Watch Me Work' Dashboard Not Displaying Data (Rate Limit)

labels.name: bug
labels.description: Something isn't working

labels.name: frontend
labels.description: Related to frontend UI and UX

labels.name: P1: High
labels.description: High priority; should be addressed soon

data.body:
### Problem
The `watch-me-work.html` dashboard, designed to display live GitHub activity, is currently unable to fetch and display data. This is due to its implementation making direct API calls to `api.github.com` from client-side JavaScript (`assets/watch-me-work.js`).

### Root Cause
Client-side direct calls to the GitHub API are subject to severe rate limits (60 requests per hour per IP for unauthenticated requests) and cannot securely utilize Personal Access Tokens (PATs). This leads to rapid exhaustion of the rate limit, preventing data from being loaded. Exposing PATs in client-side code is also a significant security vulnerability.

### Impact
The "Watch Me Work" dashboard is non-functional, failing to provide real-time insights into development activity.

### Current Implementation Analysis
- `assets/watch-me-work.js` contains `loadUserActivity()`, `loadRepositoryData()`, `loadRecentCommits()`, and `loadIssuesAndPRs()` functions that directly `fetch` data from `https://api.github.com`.
- `CONFIG.USERNAME` is hardcoded, and no authentication mechanism is used for these client-side requests.

### Proposed Solution
The `watch-me-work.html` dashboard should be refactored to consume pre-processed GitHub activity data, aligning with the existing architecture where data is collected and processed within the GitHub Actions environment.

**Phase 1: Data Export from CI**
1.  Modify the `activity-analyzer.js` script (or a new dedicated script) to export the relevant GitHub activity data (e.g., recent commits, issues, PRs, repository stats) into a static JSON file (e.g., `data/watch-me-work-data.json`) after each successful CI run.
2.  Ensure this JSON file is committed to the repository and deployed with GitHub Pages.

**Phase 2: Client-Side Consumption**
1.  Update `assets/watch-me-work.js` to fetch data from this static `data/watch-me-work-data.json` file instead of making direct GitHub API calls.
2.  Implement client-side filtering and display logic based on this pre-processed data.

This approach will:
-   Resolve GitHub API rate limit issues for the dashboard.
-   Eliminate security risks associated with client-side API key exposure.
-   Ensure the dashboard always displays the latest data processed by the CI pipeline.

### Acceptance Criteria
- `watch-me-work.html` dashboard successfully loads and displays GitHub activity data.
- No direct GitHub API calls are made from `assets/watch-me-work.js`.
- GitHub activity data is pre-processed and served statically.

### Priority
P1: High (Dashboard is a key visualization feature and currently non-functional).

commit.message:
fix: Resolve Watch Me Work dashboard data issues (rate limiting)

üéØ **Problem Solved**: Watch Me Work dashboard was non-functional due to:
- Client-side GitHub API calls hitting rate limits (60 requests/hour)

- Multiple concurrent API calls exhausting quota quickly

üîß **Solution Implemented**:

**1. Server-side Data Processing Pipeline**
- Created `watch-me-work-data-processor.js` for authenticated GitHub API access
- Processes all data server-side with full API access and rate limiting protection
- Generates static JSON file (`data/watch-me-work-data.json`) for client consumption

**2. Updated Dashboard Client**
- Replaced direct GitHub API calls with static data loading
- Added comprehensive error handling and fallback mechanisms
- Enhanced UI with loading states, error messages, and retry functionality
- Maintained all existing features while eliminating rate limit issues

**3. GitHub Actions Integration**
- Added Watch Me Work data processing step to CV enhancement workflow
- Runs after GitHub activity collection with authenticated access
- Generates fresh data every 6 hours automatically

**4. Enhanced Features**:
- Pre-computed metrics for better performance
- Smart repository filtering (includes forks with recent activity)

- Detailed error states with user-friendly messages

**üìä Technical Details**:
- Eliminates ~100+ API calls per dashboard load
- Reduces client-side API requests from 100+ to 1 static file fetch
- Uses authenticated GitHub API in CI/CD for full access
- Processes up to 100 activities, 50 commits, 30 issues/PRs per refresh

**‚úÖ Results**:
- Dashboard now loads reliably without rate limit errors
- Data stays fresh through automated CI/CD pipeline
- Better performance with pre-processed data
- Enhanced error handling and user experience

Fixes #116
